item.title: Global economic costs of aquatic invasive alien species
item.description: We use the Invacost database to aggregate reported economic costs of aquatic invasive species. Aquatic invasions have cost the global economy more than $345 billion dollars, with most of those costs due to invertebrates. Evidence suggests these costs are severely underestimated. url_pdf = “https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048969721003041"

item.title: Deep learning and ecological time series
item.description: We provide an accessible framework for applying deep learning methods for classifying time series to ecological questions. Using mcfly and TensorFlow, we demonstrate the value of these approaches for species distribution models, phenological predictions, and species identification from wingbeat spectra. url_pdf = “https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1574954121000431"

item.title: Invacost R package available
item.description: This R package provides access to the Invacost database and several methods for using and analyzing the data. This includes standardizing costs and estimating trends over time. The database is the most complete source for information on economic costs of invasive species published in peer-reviewed and grey literature, across several languages. url_pdf = “https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/invacost/index.html"

item.title: Invasive species ecology
item.description: A current focus of my research is forecasting the potential distributions of invasive species, including dreissenid mussels and lionfish. I am using a combination of parametric and non-parametric models, including application of novel machine learning approaches. In addition to commonly considered climatic predictors I am working on applications of deep learning that use time series of climate data directly. I am also currently working with the Invacost project to better understand the economic costs of non-native species.
